newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asia Product Swap - Gas oil steady in quiet trade.
newsitem.headline: Asia Product Swap - Gas oil steady in quiet trade.

text.p: Singapore gas oil swaps were steady at midday in quiet trade as the market consolidated its early week gains following unexpectedly strong physical buying support, traders said on Wednesday.
"Gas oil is hovering at the higher level right now after the big gains earlier in the week," one trader said.
August swaps were last quoted at $22.15/$22.25 per barrel, up marginally from Tuesday's $22.10/$22.20 per barrel, brokers said.
The market is currently up about 60 cents from its quotes of $21.55/$21.65 on Monday morning.
Traders said the increase in prices are due to the renewed buying interest from several players in the belief that supplies are tightening from natural demand and a cut in output.
Lower supplies were attributed to cuts in refinery runs in Singapore, maintenance shutdowns in Indonesia and reverse arbitrage exports from the region to the West.
The shutdown of Shell Singapore's 82,000-barrel-per-day gas oil unit for a 21-day maintenance in early August will also help in reducing high domestic supplies, traders said.

Singapore's weekly middle distillate stocks for the week ending July 16 was down 849,000-barrels to 10.615 million barrels which others said is still high compared to the usual six to eight million barrels.
In the physical market on Tuesday, a buyer emerged for a cargo that was offered at $21.50 per barrel free-on-board Singapore basis but no deal was concluded due to operational differences.
The buying level was 30 cents above Monday's highest traded price.
On Monday, four deals totalling 670,000 barrels were done between $20.90 and $21.20 per barrel on a free-on-board Singapore basis.
The fuel oil market is steady with August last quoted at $98.50/$99.50, brokers said.
